comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: The Guildhall was opened in July 1890. The clock has not been installed at the time of this photo. Google Street View

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: Everyone very well dressed. No barefoot urchins about.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: The Guildhall Clock was installed in 1891.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] Aha, thanks Gerry! So then 1890 is looking correct for this photo:  a) absence of clock; and b) flags in celebration of the opening?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] It's donkeys years since I was in Derry and I'm amazed at the steepness of the street there.  It either was or had just stopped raining.  Most of the flags are either meaningless or displayed out of their natural environment.

comment.author: 77318933@N08
comment._content: thinkin about it ... this image can be partially colored i guess by comparing tonalities - I've seen some German documentary about how they colored WW I and pre-WW I footage in some methods like that.

comment.author: 37107521@N00
comment._content:
added a note about an odd looking structure on the roof at right top mid of picture ;
and Gerry Ward seems to have spotted a common mistake with union flags going upsidey downsie!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/foxglove] I was looking at the telegraph pole object and going to joke that it was an anti-aircraft device as our friend teufelbeutel would suggest.  It must have been a telegraph pole even though it would have been early days.  You will occasionally see dovecotes built like that but the height would be impractical to permit caring for the birds.  It certainly isn't a TV aeriel even though they had them in Derry before we got them down south;-)

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Not too early for a telegraph pole! By 1890 there were transatlantic telegraph cables, and telegraph wires all the way to India!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: A nice Bird's Eye view in Bing.

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: As far as I can make out the USA flag has 40 stars which makes it 1889 vintage.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] The US flag went from 38 stars (Jul 1877) to 43 stars (Jul 1890); 44 (1891); 45 (1896).  Of course it could always be an old flag.

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content:
Another lovely old picture that gets a lot of attention NLI, you have the touch, you have the touch!
I look forward all the time now to see what you will come up with next so once again thank you for sharing, great work.

comment.author: 7945368@N05
comment._content: I'd say it was taken round about the front entrance to the Richmond Centre.  The people promenading on the Walls.  For years you couldn't do that, during the Troubles, as they were all closed off.
